Ans. B) The statement A is false, the statement B is true

 

Explanation:

 

  • The Basal Metabolic Rate (BMR) is defined as the metabolic rate determined in the thermoneutral zone at rest, preferably 12-14 hours after the last food intake
  • In an average man, the BMR will be about 2000 kcal / day
  • The BMR will be influenced by various factors such as age, gender, height, body weight, surface area and body temperature
  • The intake of food will increase the BMR, so in fasting or starvation, the BMR will be decreased

 

Educational Objective:

 

The objective is to understand the factors affecting Basal Metabolic Rate (BMR) and the timing of its measurement relative to food intake.

 

Ref: Ganong’s Review of Medical physiology 25th edition, pg no: 488

questions.text: When the response produced inhibits the stimuli and decreases the response, it is known as negative feedback. All the following involve this type of regulatory mechanisms except:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Onset of Labor

 

Option D: Labor is an example of positive feedback. The release of oxytocin increases uterine contractions, which in turn stimulates more oxytocin release through Hypothalamus, intensifying the contractions until delivery.

 

The mechanism of oxytocin which is associated with positive feedback. The release of oxytocin leads to actions that stimulate our pituitary gland to release even more of it.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Regulation of Temperature: The body maintains its (Shell or skin) temperature through negative feedback. When body temperature rises, mechanisms like sweating are activated to cool it down; when it falls, mechanisms like shivering are activated to warm it up. Regulation of Core body (Blood and deep viscera) temperature is a feedforward mechanism, but when its not specified whether it’s a core or shell body temperature, decision of a correct answer made on the basis of other options via exclusion criteria.

 

Option B. Thyroxine and TSH: The thyroid gland produces thyroxine under the stimulation of Thyroid Stimulating Hormone (TSH). High levels of thyroxine inhibit the release of TSH, demonstrating a classic negative feedback loop.

 

Option C. Glucose and Insulin: Insulin is released by the pancreas in response to high blood glucose levels. Insulin facilitates the uptake of glucose by cells, lowering blood glucose levels, thus inhibiting further insulin release.

 

Educational Objective:

 

To understand the concept of negative feedback and differentiate it from positive feedback, using examples of various regulatory mechanisms in the human body. This aids in comprehending how homeostasis is maintained and how certain processes like labor deviate from this typical feedback pattern.

 

Ref: Guyton and Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology, 2nd South Asia edition(13th Edition), pg no : 6-7

questions.text:
During a routine check-up, a 40-year-old male presents with concerns about unexplained weight gain, fatigue, and cold intolerance. The physician suspects hypothyroidism and considers evaluating the patient's basal metabolic rate (BMR) for further assessment. Which of the following statements accurately represent aspects related to BMR in clinical practice?

 

  1. BMR correlates with Body Weight, often higher in individuals with Greater Body lean Mass.
  2. An Average Man typically exhibits a BMR around 2000 kcal/day, subject to individual variations and factors.
  3. In Hypothyroidism, there's a notable Decrease in BMR due to Reduced Thyroid Hormone levels impacting Metabolic Rate.
  4. BMR assessment ideally occurs in a Thermoneutral Zone to avoid the influence of External Temperature on Metabolic Measurements
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1, 2, 3, 4

 

Explanation:

 

All the above statements are correct.

 

  • The Basal Metabolic Rate (BMR) is defined as the metabolic rate determined in the thermoneutral zone at rest, preferably 12-14 hours after the last food intake
  • In an average man, the BMR will be about 2000 kcal / day.
  • The BMR will be influenced by various factors such as age, gender, height, body weight, surface area and body temperature. Larger bodies have more metabolizing tissue (especially lean muscle mass), which requires more energy to maintain. 
  • The thyroid hormones will increase the basal metabolic rate via increasing the activity of Na+ K+ pump and adrenergic receptors, so in hypothyroidism, BMR will be decreased and in hyperthyroidism, BMR will be increased

 

Educational Objective:

 

To understand the concept and clinical implications of BMR, including its relationship with body weight, average values, influence of thyroid function, and the importance of the measurement environment. This knowledge is critical for assessing metabolic health and diagnosing metabolic disorders.

 

Ref: Ganong’s Review of Medical physiology 25th edition, pg no: 488

questions.text: During a routine health assessment, a 30-year-old male undergoes laboratory tests, including arterial blood gas analysis. Considering his overall health status, what range of arterial blood pH would be considered within the normal physiological limits?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 7.35 – 7.45

 

Explanation:

 

In a healthy adult, the normal PH range of the blood (plasma) will be 7.35 – 7.45 (commonly used as 7.4 for calculations).

 

  • The pH of any solution can be defined as the negative logarithm of the concentration of the hydrogen ions [H+]
  • In a healthy adult, the normal PH range of the blood (plasma) will be 7.35 – 7.45
  • When the blood pH falls below 7.35, it will be called as acidosis, where the hydrogen ion concentration will be increased
  • When the blood pH rises above 7.45, it will be called as alkalosis, where the hydrogen ion concentration will be decreased

 

Educational Objective:

 

To understand the normal range of arterial blood pH in the human body and its significance in maintaining homeostasis, crucial for diagnosing and managing acid-base imbalances in clinical practice.

 

Ref: Ganong’s Review of Medical physiology 25th edition, pg no: 5

choices.text: Calcium Channels

questions.text: During a discussion on the fundamental factors influencing Basal Metabolic Rate (BMR) among medical students, a physician emphasizes the crucial role of a specific cellular mechanism. Which of the following cellular pumps or channels significantly contributes to the energy expenditure associated with maintaining BMR in cells?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Na+/K+ ATPase

 

Option C: Na+/K+ ATPase: This pump is vital for maintaining the electrochemical gradient across cell membranes by actively transporting Na+ out of and K+ into the cell. It is a major consumer of ATP in cells, significantly contributing to the BMR.

 

Na+/K+ ATPase is a major contributing factor to Basal Metabolic Rate

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. H+/K+ ATPase: This enzyme, also known as the Proton Pump, is primarily involved in gastric acid secretion in the stomach. While it does consume ATP, its contribution to the overall BMR is relatively minor compared to other cellular mechanisms.

 

Option B. Osmosis: Osmosis is the passive movement of water across a semi-permeable membrane and does not directly require ATP. Therefore, it contributes minimally to energy expenditure and, by extension, to BMR.

 

Option D. Calcium Channels: While calcium channels play important roles in cellular signaling and muscle contraction, their direct contribution to BMR is less significant compared to the energy consumed by the Na+/K+ ATPase.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understand the role of various cellular pumps and channels in energy expenditure, with a focus on the Na+/K+ ATPase's significant contribution to the Basal Metabolic Rate, a key concept in cellular physiology and energy metabolism.

 

Ref: Ganong’s Review of Medical physiology 25th edition, pg no: 51

questions.text: While maintaining the homeostasis via specific regulatory mechanisms of the body,the response produced after giving the stimulus, increases the stimuli (in a loop) to produce further increased response. Which of the following hormones is associated with such regulatory mechanisms?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Oxytocin

 

Option B: Oxytocin is involved in childbirth and lactation and is a classic example of positive feedback. During labor, oxytocin increases uterine contractions, which in turn stimulate more oxytocin release, enhancing contractions until delivery.

 

Oxytocin is associated with positive feedback mechanism. The release of oxytocin leads to actions that stimulate your pituitary gland to release even more of it.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Testosterone, a steroid hormone, primarily follows negative feedback mechanisms. Increased levels of testosterone typically inhibit the release of Luteinizing Hormone (LH) and Follicle Stimulating Hormone (FSH), thus reducing further testosterone production.

 

Option C. Calcitonin is involved in calcium regulation and generally operates via negative feedback. It lowers blood calcium levels and its release is stimulated by high calcium levels, but it does not amplify the stimulus in a feedback loop.

 

Option D. Glucagon, involved in glucose metabolism, primarily operates through negative feedback. It raises blood glucose levels, and its secretion is stimulated by low blood glucose levels, but does not engage in a positive feedback loop.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understand the difference between positive and negative feedback mechanisms in hormonal regulation, specifically recognizing hormones like oxytocin that operate on a positive feedback loop.

 

Ref: Guyton and Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology, 2nd South Asia edition (13th Edition), pg no: 6-7

choices.text: Increased Capillary Permeability due to Inflammation or Injury
Elevated Hydrostatic Pressure within the Capillaries
Impaired Lymphatic Drainage leading to Inadequate Lymph Flow
Enhanced Levels of Plasma Proteins exerting Increased Oncotic Pressure

questions.text: A 52-year-old male was admitted to the general medicine inpatient ward with complaints of severe breathlessness and generalized body swelling. Considering the multi-factorial aspects of edema development, which among the following factors is the LEAST likely to significantly contribute to the pathogenesis of edema in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Enhanced Levels of Plasma Proteins exerting Increased Oncotic Pressure

 

Option D: Enhanced Levels of Plasma Proteins: High levels of plasma proteins typically increase oncotic pressure within the capillaries, drawing fluid into the vascular compartment, thus counteracting edema. In this scenario, enhanced plasma protein levels would be least likely to contribute to edema.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Increased Capillary Permeability: Inflammation or injury can increase capillary permeability, allowing fluid to leak into the interstitial space, contributing to edema.

 

Option B. Elevated Hydrostatic Pressure: Increased hydrostatic pressure in the capillaries, often due to conditions like heart failure, can push fluid out of the capillaries and into the interstitial space, leading to edema.

 

Option C. Impaired Lymphatic Drainage: When lymphatic drainage is impaired, lymphatic fluid accumulates in the interstitial space, contributing to swelling or edema.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understand the pathophysiological mechanisms contributing to edema, including factors that either promote or inhibit fluid accumulation in tissues. This knowledge is crucial for diagnosing and managing conditions that lead to edema.Top of Form

 

# Extra edge:

 

Different starling forces (exchange forces) which contribute in the movement of fluids across the capillaries are:

 

  1. Hydrostatic Pressure (P): 
    1. Capillaries (Pc): 25 mmHg
    2. Interstitial space (Pi): 2 mmHg (negative) But it is positive in muscle, liver and brain

 

  1. Colloid oncotic pressure (p) : contributory factor is Albumin
  1. Capillaries (p c): 25 mmHgb
  2. Interstitial space (pi): 3 mmHg

 

Ref: Ganong’s Review of Medical physiology 25th edition, pg no: 582

choices.text: Plasma Volume, accounting for approximately 5% of Body Weight, can be measured using Evan’s Blue Dye.
Plasma accounts for 25% of Body Weight & can be measured by Evan’s Blue Dye.
Intra-Cellular Fluid (ICF) constitutes about 40% of the body weight and can be estimated using substances like deuterium oxide and inulin..
Total Body Water constitutes around 60% of Body Weight and can be measured using Tritium Oxide or Deuterium Oxide.

questions.text: In a discussion about body fluid compartments and their clinical assessment, a group of medical students is presented with various statements. Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding the measurement and proportion of different fluid compartments in the human body?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Plasma accounts for 25% of Body Weight & can be measured by Evan’s Blue Dye.

 

Option B: Plasma Volume:  Plasma only accounts for about 5% of the body weight (25% of ECF). The statement is incorrect in terms of the percentage of body weight that plasma represents.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Plasma Volume: Plasma volume indeed constitutes about 5% of body weight, not 25%. Evan’s Blue dye is used for its measurement as it binds to plasma albumin, allowing for the calculation of plasma volume.

 

Option C. Intracellular Fluid: ICF makes up about 40% of body weight. Deuterium oxide (heavy water- used for TBW) and Inulin (used for ECF) can be used to measure ICF via indirect method (ICF =TBW- ECF), as it diffuses throughout the body water, including the intracellular compartment.

 

Option D. Total Body Water: Total body water does indeed constitute about 60% of body weight in a healthy adult. Tritium oxide or deuterium oxide can be used for its measurement, as these substances distribute throughout all body water compartments.

 

Educational Objective:

 

To understand the distribution and measurement of different body fluid compartments, crucial for fluid management and understanding patho-physiology in clinical practice.

 

Ref: Guyton and Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology, 2nd South Asia edition (13th Edition), pg no: 46

choices.text: Antipyrine, Inulin
Tritium, Sucrose
Thiosulfate, Inulin
Evans Blue, Antipyrine

questions.text: In a 30 year old male patient presenting with suspected fluid imbalance or renal dysfunction, precise measurement of extracellular fluid volume becomes paramount for accurate diagnosis and management. Which of the following dyes can be used to measure the given compartment.
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Thiosulfate, Inulin

 

Option C: Thiosulfate, Inulin: Thiosulfate distributes throughout the extracellular fluid, making it a suitable marker for ECF volume. Inulin, a fructose polymer, is also used to measure ECF as it does not readily cross cell membranes.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Antipyrine, Inulin: Antipyrine diffuses into both extracellular and intracellular fluids and therefore measures total body water rather than just ECF. Inulin is indeed used to measure extracellular fluid but not in combination with antipyrine for this purpose.

 

Option B. Tritium, Sucrose: Tritium measures total body water, not specifically ECF. Sucrose, while it remains in the extracellular space, is not commonly used for this measurement.

 

Option D. Evans Blue, Antipyrine: Evans Blue dye binds to plasma proteins and is used to measure plasma volume, not the entire ECF. Antipyrine measures total body water, not just ECF.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understand and identify the substances used for measuring various fluid compartments in the body, particularly the extracellular fluid, which is vital in diagnosing and managing fluid imbalances and renal disorders.

 

Indicators of measurement of body fluids:

 

 

Ref: Guyton and Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology, 2nd South Asia edition (13th Edition), pg no: 49

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presents to the emergency department with confusion, excessive thirst, and dry mucous membranes. He has a history of uncontrolled diabetes mellitus. Laboratory investigations indicate markedly elevated blood glucose levels and signs of dehydration. Which of the following associations regarding fluid compartments in an average healthy 40-year-old man is incorrectly matched?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Plasma – 5L

 

Option A: Plasma - 5 L: Plasma volume typically constitutes about 5% of body weight in a healthy adult (When the weight is not mentioned, it is taken as 70 kg), which for an average adult male translates to approximately 3.5 liters (Not 5L). Hence this option is incorrectly matched.

 

Body Fluid compartments:

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Interstitial Fluid - 10.5: Interstitial fluid volume is approximately 15% of body weight- i.e-70Kg in a healthy individual  For an average adult male, this volume is correctly estimated to be around 10.5 liters.

 

Option C. Intracellular Fluid (ICF) - 28 L: ICF makes up about 40% of body weight in a healthy adult. For an average adult male, 28 liters is a reasonable estimate for the volume of ICF.

 

Option D. Total Body Water (TBW) - 42 L: Total body water in a healthy adult male typically constitutes about 60% of body weight. For an average 70 kg male, this would be closer to 42 liters. However, given the patient's diabetes and symptoms suggesting dehydration, TBW would likely be less than the normative value stated here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

To understand the distribution of fluid compartments in the body and how conditions like diabetes and dehydration can impact these volumes, crucial for effective clinical assessment and management of fluid imbalances.

 

Ref: Guyton and Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology, 2nd South Asia edition (13th Edition), pg no: 46

choices.text: Statement A is Correct, statement B is Incorrect
Statement A is Incorrect, statement B is Correct
Both the statements A and B are Correct
Both the statements A and B are Incorrect

questions.text:
Statement A: Inulin, a polysaccharide derived from certain plant roots, is employed as an accurate marker to measure the extracellular fluid volume due to its limited cellular permeability and negligible reabsorption or metabolic alterations within the body's compartments.

 

Statement B: Contrary to common assumptions, iothalamic acid, a radiopaque contrast agent primarily utilized in diagnostic imaging procedures, is effectively utilized to assess the plasma volume based on its distribution solely within the vascular space, evading interactions with erythrocytes and plasma proteins

 

Which of the following is true regarding these two statements?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Statement A is Correct, statement B is Incorrect

 

Explanation:

 

  • Inulin is used to measure the Extra-Cellular Fluid (ECF) Volume
  • Iothalamic Acid  (125I – Iothalamate) is also used to measure the Extra-Cellular Fluid Volume
  • The other indicators used to measure the ECF volume are 22Na and Thiosulfate
  • The Plasma Volume can be measured by Evans Blue Dye and 125 I –Albumin

 

- Indicators of Measurement of Body Fluids:

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

To understand and differentiate between the substances used for measuring different body fluid compartments, particularly focusing on the accuracy and specificity of inulin for measuring extracellular fluid volume and the limitations of iothalamic acid for assessing plasma volume. This knowledge is crucial for accurate fluid compartment analysis in clinical practice.

 

Ref: Guyton and Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology, 2nd South Asia edition (13th Edition), pg no: 49

choices.text: Sodium and Chloride predominantly reside in the Extra-Cellular Fluid (ECF), playing crucial roles in maintaining Osmotic Balance and Electrical Potential across Cell Membranes.
Phosphates primarily exist Intracellularly, contributing to various Cellular Functions, and they represent the Predominant Intracellular Cations.
Potassium, a crucial ion for Cellular Excitability and numerous Intracellular Processes, predominates within the Intracellular Fluid (ICF) Compartment.
Magnesium, an essential cofactor for Enzymatic Reactions and Cellular Functions, exists abundantly in the Intracellular Compartment, particularly within the Mitochondria.

questions.text: Among the following statements concerning the distribution of ions in extracellular and intracellular compartments, which statement is inaccurate based on the understanding of electrolyte distribution in the human body?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Phosphates primarily exist Intracellularly, contributing to various Cellular Functions, and they represent the Predominant Intracellular Cations.

 

Option B: Phosphates have significant intracellular roles but are not the predominant intracellular cations; instead, potassium is the primary intracellular cation playing a crucial role in various cellular functions.

 

Phosphates are important within cells but are not the predominant intracellular cations; rather, potassium holds that distinction within the intracellular space.

 

Phosphates are anions (not cations).

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Sodium and chloride predominantly occupy the extracellular fluid (ECF), playing key roles in maintaining osmotic balance and electrical potential across cell membranes, primarily in the extracellular environment.

 

Option C. Potassium is the major intracellular cation, pivotal for cellular excitability, enzymatic reactions, and other essential intracellular processes within the intracellular fluid (ICF) compartment.

 

Option D. Magnesium, although not the most abundant, is an essential intracellular ion, particularly concentrated within the mitochondria, contributing to enzymatic reactions and cellular functions in the intracellular environment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The aim is to understand the distribution and roles of major ions in the body's fluid compartments, which is fundamental in physiology and critical for diagnosing and managing electrolyte imbalances in clinical settings.

 

Ref: Guyton and Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology, 2nd South Asia edition (13th Edition), pg no: 47

questions.text: A 40-year-old man participates in a study where his body fluid compartments are assessed. His fluid compartments measured using aminopyrine and mannitol- they are 47 liters & 14 liters respectively. Calculate the intracellular fluid volume.
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 33 Liters

 

Explanation:

 

The Intra-Cellular Fluid volume is calculated by subtracting the extracellular fluid volume (14 liters) from the total body water (47 liters), resulting in 33 liters.

 

ICF = TBW – ECF

 = 47 – 14  = 33 Liters

 

Educational Objective:

 

To understand the calculation and clinical significance of different body fluid compartments, particularly intracellular fluid volume, using measurements of total body water and extracellular fluid volume.

 

Ref: Guyton and Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology, 2nd South Asia edition (13th Edition), pg no: 49

questions.text: A 55-year-old female patient with a history of congestive heart failure presents to the emergency room with symptoms of dyspnea, peripheral edema, and confusion. Her laboratory tests reveal abnormal electrolyte levels. In managing her condition, understanding the key drivers of plasma osmolarity is essential. Considering her clinical presentation and history, which of the following ions is the most critical in determining her plasma osmolarity and guiding her fluid management?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Sodium

 

Option C: Sodium: In a patient with congestive heart failure, sodium is the most significant ion affecting plasma osmolarity. It is the primary extracellular ion, and its dysregulation is often implicated in fluid overload conditions like heart failure.

 

Sodium is the major extracellular ion, and it is the major ion contributing in the plasma osmolality.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Potassium: While potassium is vital for cardiac function, its concentration in the extracellular fluid is low compared to sodium. Therefore, it has a smaller impact on plasma osmolarity, especially in the context of fluid management in heart failure.

 

Option B. Calcium: Although calcium plays a crucial role in myocardial contractility and vascular tone, its contribution to plasma osmolarity is limited due to its lower concentration in the plasma.

 

Option D. Phosphates: Despite their role in energy metabolism, phosphates predominantly reside intracellularly and do not majorly influence plasma osmolarity compared to sodium, particularly in the context of heart failure management.

 

Educational Objective:

 

To identify the primary ion responsible for plasma osmolarity, especially in patients with congestive heart failure, for effective diagnosis and management of fluid and electrolyte imbalances in complex clinical scenarios.

 

Ref: Ganong’s Review of Medical Physiology 25th edition, pg no: 8

choices.text: 2 L
3.03 L
4.3 L
5.5 L

questions.text: In a 36-year-old male, calculate the Plasma Volume, if his Blood Volume is 5.5 L and the Hematocrit is 45%?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 3.03 L

 

Explanation:

 

The total blood volume can be expressed as

 

Blood Volume = Plasma Volume / (1 – Hematocrit)

  

Plasma Volume = Blood Volume × (1 – Hematocrit)

 

Here, Blood Volume = 5.5L; Hematocrit = 45% = 45/100 = 0.45

  

Plasma Volume = 5.5 (1 – 0.45)

 = 5.5 (0.55) = 3.025 L (3.03 L)

 

Educational Objective:

 

The objective is to understand and apply the formula for calculating plasma volume using total blood volume and hematocrit values, enhancing skills in interpreting and integrating clinical laboratory data for patient assessment and management.

 

Ref: Guyton and Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology, 2nd South Asia edition (13th Edition), pg no: 49

questions.text: In a clinical research setting, determining accurate measurements of total body water (TBW) is crucial for assessing patients with various fluid balance disorders. Among the following tracers, which one is not commonly used for measuring total body water?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 22Na

 

Option D: 22Na (Sodium-22): Sodium-22 is used to measure Extracellular Fluid Volume rather than Total Body Water. It does not cross cell membranes efficiently and remains largely in the extracellular space, Hence, NOT commonly used for measuring total body water, as asked in the question.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. 3H2O (Tritiated Water): Tritiated water is a radioactive form of water used to measure TBW. It distributes evenly throughout the body’s water compartments, making it a reliable marker for total body water measurement.

 

Option B. 2H2O (Deuterium Oxide): Deuterium oxide, also known as heavy water, is non-radioactive and safe for clinical use. It evenly distributes across all body fluid compartments, allowing for accurate assessment of TBW.

 

Option C. Antipyrine: Antipyrine diffuses well into both extracellular and intracellular compartments, making it a useful marker for measuring TBW, despite being less commonly used than radioactive or stable isotopes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

To understand the methods and tracers used in measuring total body water, crucial for evaluating fluid status and managing fluid balance disorders in clinical practice.

 

Ref: Guyton and Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology, 2nd South Asia edition (13th Edition), pg no: 49

questions.text:
Identify the correct statements regarding sodium ions?

 

  1. It serves as a major Extracellular Anion, playing a pivotal role in maintaining Osmotic Balance and Electrical Potential across Cell Membranes in the Extracellular Fluid, owing to their Abundance and Positive Charge
  2. Highly Osmotically Active, Sodium ions significantly Regulate Osmolarity within the Extra-Cellular Fluid, playing a vital role in Water Balance, Cellular Volume Control, and Physiological processes within the Body.
  3. Sodium Ions actively participate in various Energy-Consuming Active Transport Mechanisms across Cellular Membranes, utilizing Adenosine Tri-Phosphate (ATP) as an Energy source, crucial for Cellular Homeostasis, Nerve Impulse Conduction, and proper Physiological Function.
  4. Blood levels of Sodium Ions typically range between 100-120 mEq/L, maintaining a Balance essential for proper Nerve Function, Muscle Contraction within an Extra-Cellular Fluid compartment.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 2,3

 

Explanation:

 

  • 1: This statement is incorrect as sodium is a major extracellular cation (not anion). Its positive charge and abundance are critical for osmotic balance and electrical potential across cell membranes in the extracellular fluid.
  • 2: Correct. Sodium ions are highly osmotically active and play a key role in regulating extracellular fluid osmolarity. This impacts water balance, cell volume, and various physiological processes.
  • 3: Correct. Sodium ions are involved in active transport mechanisms across cellular membranes, like the Na+/K+ ATPase pump, which is essential for maintaining cellular homeostasis, nerve impulse transmission, and muscle function.
  • 4: This statement is incorrect as the normal range of sodium in blood is typically between 135-145 mEq/L. The range mentioned (100-120 mEq/L) is significantly lower than the normal physiological range.

 

Educational Objective:

 

To understand the role and significance of sodium ions in maintaining physiological balance. This knowledge is crucial in the clinical assessment and management of electrolyte imbalances.

 

Ref: Ganong’s Review of Medical Physiology 25th edition, pg no: 8

questions.text: Which of the following volumes can be quantified with the help of radio isotopic chromium labelled red blood cells and the total body water (TBW) respectively?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Blood Volume; 3H2O

 

Option A: Blood Volume; 3H2O: Chromium-labeled red blood cells can be used to measure blood volume accurately, while tritiated water (3H2O) is used for Total Body Water (TBW) estimation. The blood volume can be inferred from these measurements. The ICF volume can be calculated as total body water (TBW) – ECF (difference)

 

Indicators of measurement of body fluids:

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. ICF Volume; Antipyrine: Antipyrine distributes into both extracellular and intracellular compartments and thus measures total body water, not specifically ICF volume.

 

Option C. Plasma Volume; 2H2O: Deuterium oxide (2H2O) is used to measure total body water, not specifically plasma volume. Plasma volume is typically measured using substances like Evans blue dye or radioactive iodine.

 

Option D. ECF Volume; 22Na: Sodium-22 (22Na) is used to measure the extracellular fluid volume due to its limited permeability across cell membranes. It remains within the extracellular compartment, making it suitable for ECF volume measurement.

 

Educational Objective:

 

To understand the specific isotopic methods used for accurately quantifying different body fluid compartments, essential in clinical research and the management of fluid balance disorders.

 

Ref: Guyton and Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology, 2nd South Asia edition (13th Edition), pg no: 49

questions.text: A 24 year old male was admitted at the emergency ward with a history of burn injuries. On evaluation, his hematocrit was found to be 60%. If his plasma volume was 2L, what would be his blood volume?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 5 L

 

Explanation:

 

The Total Blood Volume can be expressed as

 

Blood Volume = Plasma Volume / (1 – Hematocrit)

 

Here, plasma Volume = 2 L, Hematocrit = 60% = 60/100 = 0.6

 

Blood Volume = 2 / (1 – 0.6)

                           = 2 / (0.4) = 5 L

 

Educational Objective:

 

To apply knowledge of hematocrit and plasma volume in the calculation of total blood volume, which is essential in clinical scenarios like burn injuries for fluid management and understanding changes in blood components.

 

Ref: Guyton and Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology, 2nd South Asia edition (13th Edition), pg no: 49

questions.text:
All of the following statements about the antigens of ABO blood group system are correct except?

 

  1. These antigens encompass intricate glycoproteins, configuring the distinctive surface markers on red blood cells that serve as the foundation for blood type determination.

  2. The antigens present on the erythrocyte surface play a crucial role in immune responses, often initiating immunogenic reactions in the event of mismatched blood transfusions or organ transplants.

  3. Although widely recognized for their antigenic variability across blood types, these antigens generally exhibit low immunogenicity in terms of eliciting primary immune responses in the absence of prior sensitization.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 3 only

 

Statements 3 is wrong. (Note the words ‘true except’ in the question)

 

­Carbohydrate chains that determine the ABO blood group.

 

 

Explanation:

 

  • 1: This statement is correct. ABO antigens are indeed complex glycoproteins that act as surface markers on red blood cells, crucial for determining blood type.
  • 2: Also correct. These antigens are central to immune recognition and can lead to serious immune reactions if mismatched blood or organs are transfused or transplanted.
  • 3 (Incorrect): This statement is incorrect. ABO antigens are actually highly immunogenic, even in the absence of prior sensitization, which is why they are so critical in transfusion medicine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

To recognize the characteristics and clinical significance of ABO blood group antigens, which are essential for safe blood transfusion practices and understanding the genetic basis of blood type inheritance.

 

Ref: Ganong’s Review of Medical Physiology, 25th edition, pg no: 560

questions.text: In a 60-year-old patient with a long-standing history of chronic hemolytic disorders, the hemoglobin catabolism pathway is of particular interest due to its implications for clinical management. Following the breakdown of hemoglobin and the formation of biliverdin, which metabolite is produced in the subsequent step of heme catabolism?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Bilirubin

 

Option B: Bilirubin: Biliverdin is converted to bilirubin by the enzyme biliverdin reductase. Bilirubin is a yellow compound that causes jaundice if it accumulates, which can be a concern in hemolytic disorders.

 

Bilirubin Metabolism in our body can be shown as:

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Properdin: Properdin is a component of the complement system and is not involved in the catabolism of hemoglobin. It plays a role in the immune response rather than heme breakdown.

 

Option C. Hemosiderin: Hemosiderin is an iron storage complex and is not directly formed from biliverdin. It may accumulate in chronic hemolytic disorders but is a downstream product of hemoglobin breakdown, not directly from biliverdin.

 

Option D. Stercobilinogen: Stercobilinogen is a further breakdown product of bilirubin in the intestine. It is not directly formed from biliverdin and is part of the excretory pathway for bilirubin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

To understand the pathway of heme catabolism and the clinical significance of its end products, particularly bilirubin, which is a key metabolite whose levels are commonly measured in patients with hemolytic disorders.

 

Ref: Ganong’s Review of Medical Physiology, 25th edition, pg no: 558

choices.text: Blood group O, recognized as a universal donor due to the absence of both A and B antigens on red blood cells, genetically characterized by the genotype OA, indicating the presence of both O alleles and A alleles.
Blood group B, identified by the presence of allele B, which results in the expression of B antigens on the erythrocyte surface, the recognized genotype can be OB.
Blood group A, characterized by the presence of allele A, resulting in the expression of A antigens on red blood cells, genetically represented by the genotype AA.
Blood group AB, showcasing a unique circumstance where both A and B alleles are co-expressed, displaying both A and B antigens on red blood cells, genetically denoted by the genotype AB.

questions.text: In a comprehensive study assessing blood group genotypes within the ABO system, which of the subsequent pairings inaccurately aligns a specific blood group with its corresponding genotype?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Blood group O, recognized as a universal donor due to the absence of both A and B antigens on red blood cells, genetically characterized by the genotype OA, indicating the presence of both O alleles and A alleles.

 

Option A. Blood Group O: Blood group O is characterized by the absence of both A and B antigens, and the genotype is OO, not OA. The presence of an A allele would result in blood group A, not O.

 

O blood group phenotype can’t have genotype OA. It has no A or B antigens, it can only have OO genotype.

 

Possible genotypes within the ABO blood group system:

 

 

In this representation:

 

  • Blood group A can have genotypes AA (homozygous) or AO (heterozygous).
  • Blood group B can have genotypes BB (homozygous) or BO (heterozygous).
  • Blood group AB only has the genotype AB (co-dominant).
  • Blood group O can have genotypes ii (homozygous) or OO (homozygous) where 'i' represents the absence of A and B alleles.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Blood Group B: For blood group B, the genotype can indeed be OB (or BB), where the presence of at least one B allele leads to the expression of B antigens on the erythrocytes.

 

Option C. Blood Group A: The genotype AA correctly indicates blood group A, where the presence of A alleles results in the expression of A antigens on the red blood cells.

 

Option D. Blood Group AB: Blood group AB is the result of the codominance of A and B alleles, leading to the expression of both A and B antigens on the red blood cell surface, and is correctly represented by the genotype AB.

 

Educational Objective:

 

To understand the genetic basis of ABO blood group determination, emphasizing the importance of accurately matching genotypes to phenotypes for clinical applications such as transfusions and organ transplants.

 

Ref: Guyton and Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology, 2nd South Asia edition, pg no: 163

choices.text: The woman can be the child’s natural mother, but the man cannot be the natural father
The man can be the child’s natural father, but the woman cannot be the natural mother
Neither adult can be the natural parent of this child
This couple can be the natural parents of this child

questions.text: A woman whose blood type is A, Rh positive, and a man whose blood type is B, Rh positive, come to the clinic with a 3-year-old girl whose blood type is O, Rh negative.What can be said about the relationship of these two adults to this child?
questions.solution:
Ans. D - This couple can be the natural parents of this child

 

  1. Understanding ABO Blood Type Inheritance:
    1. Blood type is inherited based on the ABO gene, which has three alleles: A, B, and O.
    2. Each parent passes one allele to the child.
    3. Possible genotype combinations:
      1. Blood type A can be AA or AO.
      2. Blood type B can be BB or BO.
      3. Blood type O can only be OO (inherits one O allele from each parent).
  2. Determining Child’s Blood Type (O) Possibility:
    1. The mother is A, which means her genotype could be AA or AO.
    2. The father is B, meaning his genotype could be BB or BO.
    3. If the mother is AO and the father is BO, they can both pass the O allele, resulting in a child with OO (blood type O).
  3. Understanding Rh Factor Inheritance:
    1. Rh factor is inherited separately.
    2. The Rh+ (positive) allele is dominant, and the Rh- (negative) allele is recessive.
    3. Since both parents are Rh positive, their genotypes can be either:
      1. Rh+/Rh+ (homozygous dominant) → Only passes Rh+.
      2. Rh+/Rh- (heterozygous) → Can pass either Rh+ or Rh-.
  4. Can the Child be Rh Negative?
    1. For the child to be Rh-, they must inherit the Rh- allele from both parents.
    2. If both parents are heterozygous Rh+ (Rh+/Rh-), each has a 50% chance of passing Rh-.
    3. If both pass Rh-, the child will be Rh-.
  5. Final Conclusion:
    1. If the mother is AO and the father is BO, the child can inherit O from both → Blood type O.
    2. If both parents are heterozygous Rh+ (Rh+/Rh-), the child can inherit Rh- from both → Rh negative.
    3. Therefore, this couple can be the biological parents of the child.

 

Educational Objective:


Blood type inheritance follows Mendelian genetics where the ABO system is determined by codominant alleles, and the Rh factor follows a dominant-recessive pattern. Parents with blood types A and B can have a child with blood type O if they carry the O allele. Similarly, two Rh+ parents can have an Rh- child if both are heterozygous (Rh+/Rh-).

choices.text: The Average Lifespan of a Red Blood Cell within Circulation Spans approximately 120 days, after which they undergo Phagocytosis primarily within the Spleen and Liver.
On average, each Red Blood Cell contains approximately 29 Picograms of Hemoglobin, crucial for Oxygen Transport and release throughout the Circulatory System.
Red Blood Cells possess a diameter averaging around 4.5 µm, allowing for optimal passage through Narrow Capillaries and facilitating Gas Exchange within Tissues.
Red Blood Cells exhibit a Thickness close to 2 µm, ensuring Flexibility and Adaptability, facilitating their passage through Microvasculature and Capillary Networks.

questions.text: In a examination of red blood cell characteristics, all of the following statements accurately delineates features of these cells, except for one that contains an inaccuracy, Identify the inaccurate statement?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Red Blood Cells possess a diameter averaging around 4.5 µm, allowing for optimal passage through Narrow Capillaries and facilitating Gas Exchange within Tissues.

 

Option C: Diameter of 4.5 µm (Incorrect): The average diameter of a red blood cell is about 7.5 to 8 µm, not 4.5 µm. This diameter facilitates the RBC's passage through capillaries and is critical for efficient gas exchange.

 

Different dimensions of erythrocyte (RBCs) are:

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. 120-Day Lifespan: Red blood cells (RBCs) do have an average lifespan of 120 days in circulation, after which they are typically phagocytosed by macrophages in the spleen and liver.

 

Option B. 29 Picograms of Hemoglobin: While the amount of hemoglobin in an RBC is roughly 30 picograms, 29 picograms is a reasonable average, making this statement largely accurate.

 

Option D. Thickness of 2 µm: RBCs are biconcave disks with a thickness at the thickest point of about 2 µm. This structure contributes to their flexibility and ability to deform as they pass through the microvasculature.

 

  • In adults, RBCs will be manufactured from the bone marrow and their average life duration will be 120 days
  • Each red blood cell will have around 29 pg of hemoglobin

 

Educational Objective:

 

To recognize the normal physical characteristics of red blood cells, which are critical for their function in oxygen transport and passage through the microcirculation, essential knowledge in both normal physiology and in the clinical assessment of hematologic health.

 

Ref: Ganong’s Review of Medical Physiology, 25th edition, pg no: 555

questions.text:
In the stored blood at a blood bank, the biochemical changes observed in the blood were analysed. Which of the following changes can be expected in the stored blood?

 

  1. Increased Glycolysis
  2. Decreased Adenine
  3. Decreased 2,3-BPG
  4. ATP Depletion
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 2, 3, 4

 

Statements 2, 3 and 4 show the changes that happen in the stored blood. Glycolysis is decreased (not increased).

 

Explanation:

 

  • Increased Glycolysis: This is not typically seen in stored blood. Glycolysis may initially increase after collection but will decrease over time as glucose levels in the storage medium are depleted.
  • Decreased Adenine: Correct. Adenine levels, which are necessary for ATP synthesis, decrease in stored blood due to the lack of new synthesis and ongoing consumption.
  • Decreased 2, 3-BPG: Correct. 2,3-BPG levels in red blood cells decrease during storage, which affects oxygen delivery capability because 2,3-BPG stabilizes the deoxygenated form of hemoglobin
  • ATP Depletion: Correct. ATP levels deplete over time in stored blood due to the lack of substrate for glycolysis and the ongoing consumption for maintaining ion gradients and cell integrity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

To understand the biochemical changes that occur in stored blood, which can impact the efficacy and safety of transfusions, and to recognize these changes as part of the storage lesion in banked blood.

 

Ref: Guyton and Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology, 2nd South Asia edition, pg no: 167

The Statement A is False, the Statement B is True

questions.text:
Statement A: Type A blood groups is associated with terminal N-acetyl glucosamine on H antigen

 

Statement B: Type B blood group is associated with terminal galactose on H antigen

 

Which of the following is true about these statements?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) The Statement A is False, the Statement B is True

 

Explanation:

 

  • The Transferase in A Blood Group (A Antigen) will place a terminal N-acetylgalactosamine on the H antigen (not glucosamine)
  • The transferase in B Blood Group (B Antigen) will place a terminal galactose on the H Antigen
  • The AB type blood group (both A and B antigens) will have both the transferases, whereas in O type blood group (neither A nor B antigens), both these transferases will be absent (only H antigen will be there)

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

To understand the specific carbohydrate structures that define the ABO blood group antigens and how they modify the H antigen, which is crucial for correctly interpreting blood group characteristics and ensuring safe blood transfusions.

 

Ref: Ganong’s Review of Medical Physiology, 25th edition, pg no: 558, 559

choices.text: Alpha 2, Beta 2
Alpha 2, Delta 2
Beta 2, Gamma 2
Alpha 2, Gamma 2

questions.text: A 32-year-old patient with a history of Chronic Anemia undergoes specialized laboratory investigations. Hemoglobin electrophoresis reveals the presence of a distinct hemoglobin subtype, HbA2, necessitating precise identification of its polypeptide chains for accurate diagnosis and management.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Alpha 2, Delta 2

 

Option B: HbA2 is composed of two alpha chains and two delta chains. An increased level of HbA2 can be indicative of beta-thalassemia.

 

Structure of Human Hemoglobin. α and β globin subunits are in red and blue, respectively, and the iron-containing heme groups in green.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Alpha 2, Beta 2: This represents the polypeptide chains of the most common adult hemoglobin, HbA, not HbA2.

 

Option C. Beta 2, Gamma 2: This composition is incorrect for any normal adult hemoglobin. Gamma chains are present in fetal hemoglobin (HbF), not HbA2.

 

Option D. Alpha 2, Gamma 2: This describes fetal hemoglobin (HbF), not HbA2.

 

Educational Objective:

 

To understand the structure and clinical significance of different hemoglobin types, especially the role of HbA2 in the diagnosis of hemoglobinopathies such as thalassemia.

 

Ref:  Ganong’s Review of Medical physiology, 25th edition, pg no: 555

choices.text: Heme Reductase, an Enzyme crucial for the Reduction of Heme and prevention of Oxidative Stress-induced Damage in Erythrocytes.
Heme Dehydrogenase, an enzyme primarily responsible for the Oxidation of Heme to form Biliverdin, initiating the breakdown process in Red Blood Cells.
Heme Oxygenase, an essential Enzyme catalyzing the Rate-limiting step in Heme Degradation, leading to the production of Biliverdin, Carbon Monoxide, and Iron.
Biliverdin Synthase, an enzyme involved in the subsequent conversion of Heme to Biliverdin, playing an important role in the steps of Heme Catabolism.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents to the emergency department with symptoms of severe jaundice following a recent episode of hemolysis due to an underlying autoimmune disorder. Laboratory investigations reveal elevated levels of unconjugated bilirubin in the serum. Further assessment indicates a breakdown of heme leading to the production of biliverdin. Which of the following enzymes plays a pivotal role in the conversion of heme to biliverdin within the heme catabolic pathway?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Heme Oxygenase, an essential enzyme catalyzing the rate-limiting step in Heme Degradation, leading to the production of Biliverdin, Carbon Monoxide, and Iron.

 

Option C: Heme oxygenase is the key enzyme in the catabolism of heme, catalyzing the rate-limiting step that results in the breakdown of Heme into Biliverdin, Carbon Monoxide, and free iron. This process is crucial in conditions of Hemolysis and Elevated Unconjugated Bilirubin.

 

Bilirubin Metabolism in our body can be shown as:

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Heme Reductase: This enzyme is not involved in the direct conversion of heme to biliverdin. Its primary function is related to reducing heme for preventing oxidative damage, not in its catabolism.

 

Option B. Heme Dehydrogenase: While this term may imply a role in heme catabolism, heme dehydrogenase is not the enzyme responsible for converting heme to biliverdin in the human body.

 

Option D. Biliverdin Synthase: This enzyme is not responsible for the initial conversion of heme to biliverdin. Heme oxygenase is the enzyme that directly mediates this conversion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

To understand the role of heme oxygenase in the heme catabolism pathway, particularly in conditions leading to hemolysis and jaundice, which is vital for diagnosing and managing disorders related to abnormal red blood cell breakdown and bilirubin metabolism.

 

Ref: Guyton and Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology, 2nd South Asia edition, pg no: 130

questions.text:
Assertion: The affinity of fetal hemoglobin for oxygen is greater than that of adult hemoglobin

 

Reason: In fetal hemoglobin, the gamma polypeptide chains bind poorly with 2, 3-DPG

 

Which of the following is true about these statements?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Both the assertion and the reason statements are correct, the reason is the correct explanation for the assertion

 

Explanation:

 

  • The Adult Hemoglobin (called HbA) will have two alpha chains and two beta chains (Alpha 2, Beta 2)
  • In Fetal Hemoglobin (called HbF), the beta chains will be replaced by gamma chains and there will be two alpha chains and two gamma chains (Alpha 2, Gamma 2)
  • The affinity of fetal hemoglobin for oxygen will be greater than that of adult hemoglobin
  • This is mainly because of the poor binding of 2, 3 – Di-Phospho-Glycerate (DPG) with the gamma chains of fetal hemoglobin. 

 

Because of this increase in affinity of fetal hemoglobin towards oxygen, the oxy-hemoglobin dissociation curve shifts towards left:

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

To understand the physiological differences between fetal and adult hemoglobin, particularly the higher oxygen affinity of fetal hemoglobin due to its reduced interaction with 2, 3-DPG, which is crucial in fetal development and oxygen transport.

 

Ref:  Ganong’s Review of Medical physiology, 25th edition, pg no: 557, 641

questions.text: A 10 year old boy was brought to the paediatric OPD with a history of recurrent episodes of swelling and redness of right knee joint, most probably due to hemarthrosis. On detailed evaluation of coagulation factors, he had deficient factor VII, but factors VIII, IX and XI were found to be normal. What will be the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hypoconvertinemia

 

Option D: Hypoconvertinemia, also known as factor VII deficiency, is the most probable diagnosis for this patient. It is characterized by a deficiency in factor VII, aligning with the patient’s clinical findings of recurrent joint swelling and hemarthrosis.

 

The deficiency of clotting factor VII will result in hypoconvertinemia.

 

Coagulation pathway showing various factors:

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Haemophilia C is a rare form of haemophilia characterized by a deficiency in factor XI, not factor VII. Given the normal factor XI levels in this patient, this diagnosis is unlikely.

 

Option B. Christmas disease, also known as haemophilia B, is caused by a deficiency in factor IX. Since this patient has normal factor IX levels, this condition does not fit his clinical profile.

 

Option C. Parahemophilia: Parahemophilia is associated with a deficiency in factor V. This diagnosis is not aligned with this patient’s presentation, as he has a factor VII deficiency and normal factor V levels are implied.

 

Educational Objective:

 

To understand and differentiate between various coagulation disorders based on the deficient factors involved, which is essential for accurate diagnosis and appropriate management of bleeding disorders in pediatric patients.

 

Ref: Ganong’s Review of Medical physiology, 25th edition, pg no: 567
